page.title: 13ECOLOGY - SYDMONTON AREA
page.content: ALTHOUGH CURRENT USE OF CHEMICALS IN FARMING HAS HAD A DRASTIC EFFECT ON WILD LIFE OVER THE LAST TWO DECADES, SCABIOUS ARE STILL FOUND ALONG THE ROAD SIDES AND COWSLIPS HAVE RETURNED DURING RECENT SUMMERS ON THE REMAINING GRASS AREAS OF DOWNLAND. THERE ARE ALSO MARBLED WHITE BUTTERFLIES IN THE WEST OF THE AREA. JUST BELOW NUTHANGER FARM, TO THE NORTH, IS A BADGER SETT TUCKED INTO THE WOODED HILLSIDE. FOXES ARE HUNTED EVERY WINTER, AND LAST WINTER DEER HAD TO BE CULLED BECAUSE OF DAMAGE TO TREES. RABBITS ARE MORE PLENTIFUL THAN HARES. MANY FOOTPATHS ARE OVERGROWN AND MANY HEDGEROWS ARE LOST; THE ELM HAS GONE COMPLETELY (DUTCH ELM DISEASE) AND THE BEECH TREES ON WATERSHIP DOWN ARE DYING. TREES ARE BEING PLANTED AGAIN IN SOME PLACES.
